item.title: Microsoft Increases OpenAI Investment
item.content:encoded:
Microsoft has announced that it’s increasing its investment in AI. On Tuesday, it was announced that the company purchased a 27% stake in OpenAI for $135 billion.

Microsoft has had a partnership with OpenAI for years, but Tuesday’s announcement increases that commitment to the AI-based company behind ChatGPT, Sora, Whisper, and more.

“What began as an investment in a research organization has grown into one of the most successful partnerships in our industry,” the joint press announcement says. “As we enter the next phase of this partnership, we’ve signed a new definitive agreement that builds on our foundation, strengthens our partnership, and sets the stage for long-term success for both organizations.”

With the added push towards AI within Microsoft, players and employees are likely to be concerned about more AI being used to develop upcoming games. On this front, Xbox’s Phil Spencer has gone on record saying that they won’t force its use on staff.

He said that AI use is left to individual teams and that he’s “found that creative teams will use tools that make their job easier when it makes their job easier, and any top-down mandate that ‘Thou must use a certain tool’…is not really a path to success.”

What do you think the future holds for AI within Microsoft and Xbox? Leave your thoughts down in the comments, and join the official Insider Gaming Discord server.

For more Insider Gaming, read about EA employees mocking the company’s mandate to use AI tools. And don’t forget to sign up for our weekly newsletter.

SUBSCRIBE to our newsletter to receive the latest news and exclusive leaks every week! No Spam.

item.title: Is The Battlefield 6 BF Pro Battle Pass Worth It? Rewards and Bonuses Explained
item.content:encoded:
Battlefield 6 Season 1 is here, and that means the arrival of new maps, modes, weapons, and the battle royale platform known as REDSEC. It also means that the game’s first Battle Pass is here, and as you probably predicted, it’s split into two tiers. In this guide, I’ll help you figure out if the Battlefield 6 BF Pro Battle Pass is worth your money.

The Battlefield Pro Battle Pass will set you back £21.99 (or your local equivalent), and the content found within will last for 12 weeks. Let’s figure out if it’s worth your time, effort, and money to invest in the rewards found in the BF Pro Battle Pass in Battlefield 6.

What Comes With the Battlefield Pro Battle Pass?

REDSEC might be free to access, but if you want to get the most from Battlefield 6, you’ll need to get a Battle Pass. There are two variants: Standard and Battlefield Pro. The former costs 1,100 Battlefield Coins (£8.99 or your local equivalent), but the BF Pro Battle Pass can only be bought with cold, hard cash.

It doesn’t matter how many BF Coins you have; you can’t use them to buy the BF Pro Battle Pass, but the rewards in the Pro Pass are much greater.

Here’s everything you get for investing in the Battlefield Pro Battle Pass:

  • Free Rewards
  • Battle Pass Rewards
  • Battle Pass Instant Unlock Rewards
  • Battle Pass 15% Progression Boost
  • 100 Max Portal Persistent Server Hosts
  • BF Pro Instant Unlock Rewards
  • 25 Battle Pass Tier Skips
  • In-Game Vehicle Radio Station
  • BF Pro Battle Pass Path
  • BF Pro Assignments

It all begins with five instant unlocks, including the new GGH-22 pistol (modelled on the Glock 22). Your 25 free tier skips will enable you to power through almost the entire first section of the Battle Pass – ‘Rogue Operators’. This puts you one step away from the new SOR-300SC carbine.

In the Instant Unlock section (for both Battle Pass and BF Pro users), you’ll get twelve items immediately, including four new operators, two weapon packages, a knife skin, a parachute skin, calling cards, and XP boosters.

Before you get too far, be sure to check out the patch notes for Battlefield 6’s 1.1.1.0 update.

Battlefield 6 Battle Pass Max Rewards

There’s a tasty reward at the end of each section in the Battle Pass:

  • Rogue Operators
  • Deniable Ops
  • Soldiers of Fortune
  • Pacific Ghosts

And then you hit the Ultimate tiers, and finally the Prestige tiers.

Here’s the final reward in each portion of the Battlefield 6 Battle Pass.

Rogue Operators – Forest Sentry

Deniable Ops – Mackenzie

Soldiers of Fortune – Health is Wealth

Pacific Ghosts – Divided Patterns

Can You Skip Sections in the Battle Pass in Battlefield 6?

If you don’t like the current path you’re on or want to target different rewards, you can switch paths at any time, making headway towards other rewards in different channels.

Only once you’ve unlocked everything can you access Ultimate and Prestige rewards. Here are the final rewards in those channels:

Ultimate – Spiteful Mirage

Prestige – Battlefield Coins

With stacks of exclusive rewards, challenges, unlocks, and the chunky experience boost being set aside for BF Pro subscribers, I think it’s more than worth the money. However, if you’re not going to invest a lot of time in Battlefield 6, then perhaps the standard edition is for you.

It’s worth stressing that you can unlock enough BF Coins in one full Battle Pass to purchase the next Battle Pass, so bear that in mind.

Are you going to buy the BF Pro Battle Pass, or are you not interested? Let me know on the Insider Gaming Discord server.

For more Battlefield coverage, check out the news that skins are being adjusted after community backlash
